stem: A 38-year-old client with 'unquenchable thirst' is undergoing a Water Deprivation Test. Based on the documentation in the Water-Deprivation & ADH Response Log, what is the most likely diagnosis?

rationale.correct: This is **Central Diabetes Insipidus (a1)**. The tests show: 1. When deprived of water, the urine stayed dilute (115 mOsm), meaning the body could not concentrate it on its own. 2. **After Desmopressin (synthetic ADH)**, the urine osmolality **increased significantly** (to 680). This proves the kidney *can* concentrate urine, it just wasn't receiving the 'signal' (ADH) from the brain. If it were Nephrogenic DI (a2), the Desmopressin would have had no effect. If it were Psychogenic Polydipsia (a3), the urine would have concentrated during the deprivation phase alone.
clinicalPearls: Water Deprivation Test = Can you concentrate urine without water?
Desmopressin Challenge = Can your kidneys listen to ADH?
Central DI = Brain doesn't make it. Nephrogenic DI = Kidney doesn't hear it.
Priority in Central DI is Vasopressin/Desmopressin therapy.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing Psychogenic Polydipsia (a3) because the client is thirsty.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In Psychogenic Polydipsia, if you take away the water, the body's *working* ADH will kick in and the urine will get concentrated. If the urine stays like 'water' (110â€“115) even when the patient is dehydrated/losing weight, it is a hormone problem (DI).

mnemonic.title: C-C Response
mnemonic.expansion: C-Central DI. C-Concentrates with injection. (Responds to Desmopressin).
